Award.AwardTitle: Guided Evolutionary Games for Influencing Interacting Agents' Behavior in Large Populations

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Swarm robotics is the use of a large number of small, simple robots to accomplish common goals, mimicking the cooperative task sharing observed naturally in hives and colonies. As this technology becomes a reality, there is an increasing need to develop methods for guiding and controlling the swarm. The standard approach to controlling a system of multiple agents relies on treating them as approximately separate, however other paradigms will be needed as the number of these agents becomes unmanageably large, and their interactions dominate their behavior. The growing success of evolutionary game theory in biology and ecology suggests a mechanism for control at the population level, in which individual interactions are manipulated to drive the agent community towards global goals. This award is concerned with developing and studying these guided evolutionary games, and testing their consequences in simulations of interacting agents. Applications include the control of microscopic robot swarms in medical applications and the guided management of online social phenomena, including the development of active influence mechanisms for decreasing negative online behaviors like cyberbullying. This project will provide valuable interdisciplinary training for young researchers, and target outreach activities towards high school students, and undergraduates.

This project takes the first steps in bridging the gap between evolutionary game theory, massively distributed mechanism design, and the design of control systems. The work focuses on semi-autonomous agents who interact with each other through localized communication, and describes their behavior via evolutionary games using either replicator or discontinuous imitation dynamics. Communications play out either on a network or in Euclidean space; both topologies increase the problem complexity and can lead to organized spatial patterns. Connections will be made systematically between microscale, agent-based simulations, and macroscale, density-based evolutionary equations, such as the replicator and other alternatives. The dynamics of hybrid controllers, that modify the game played by the interacting agents, will also be considered. Control of the population is accomplished by periodic actuation of the game governing the interactions. The goals of this project are to understand the control-theoretic preliminaries necessary to allow equilibrium shaping in order to control populations, to determine the theoretical limits of control in this setting, and finally to apply this approach to the control of autonomous agents in high-fidelity simulations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The rapidly approaching advent of massively parallel robotics (such as swarming nano-scale robots or fleets of self-driving cars) brings with it a critical problem of correspondingly massive distributed control. Due to the mathematical challenges posed by the unmanageably large number of agents, it is natural to look for other paradigms for control protocols and related theoretical developments. The goal of this project is to combine the formalisms of modern control and optimization theory with dynamical systems that arise from (various forms of) evolutionary games. One approach to controlling massive agent swarms is to program simple evolutionary rules into swarm systems at the individual level (mirroring finite population evolutionary games), and  then to actuate parameters of the game to control the evolution of the swarm, and hopefully guide it toward fixed points of the dynamical system. By studying control problems and developing new evolutionary game approaches in this setting, we seek to (i) identify novel results at the interface of control and game theory, and (ii) illustrate new tractable mechanisms for controlling complex systems of interacting agents.


This project led to several new research advances. First we developed several new results on finite population evolutionary games, as well as a novel transition matrix approach to evolutionary games with dynamics that were fundamentally different from those of the standard replicator equation. We then initiated a study of public goods games, showing that in the dynamic case, these cheating games were transformable to a generalized form of the rock-paper-scissors game. We studied a specific control problem in this context and showed intriguing closed form results for an optimal controller. We also began an investigation into consensus dynamics, replacing the classic DeGroot model for opinion dynamics with a payoff derived from a game-theoretic interaction. This work provided new results in consensus control for these highly non-linear dynamical systems. We also studied several cases of agent-based models in which, while individuals play simplified versions of standard games, the population overall evolves according to some combination of averaged and stochastic dynamics. Finally, we extended our work on public goods games and network evolutionary games to study fast cheater migration in networks. This work has led to on-going studies in spatial and network replicator dynamics that has emerged from our study in this project. 


Results from this project have been incorporated by us and our colleagues into models of human behavior in online systems. In particular, we showed that certain cyber-bullying behavior could be modeled with network replicator dynamics. In addition to this cross-disciplinary work, we have engaged in a fruitful collaboration with our colleagues at Penn State Hershey Medicine to study the use of game theory for explaining behavior in the human microbiome -- a key indicator of human health. Several undergraduate and graduate students have been supported on this program. Additionally, research performed on this project has formed a key part of both undergraduate and graduate classes that have impacted hundreds of students.
